awd_titl_txt: Study of the Regulative Role of Integrin Tension in the Formation and Function of Plasma Membrane Protrusions in Cancer Cells
awd_abstract_narration:
Metastasis, which is invasion of normal tissues by cancer cells, is the main cause of cancer patient death. The cells that metastasize have special sites on their surfaces call "invadopodia" that make it possible for the cells to spread.   Multiple lines of indirect evidence suggest that invadopodia are use mechanical loads are part of their invasion function.  How these forces function in invasion, however, remains unknown.  Two molecular tension tools were developed by the investigators and will be used to measure loading of the invadopodium.  This research will determine how tension affects invadopodia formation and facilitates cell motion. High resolution cellular force maps will also be created as a biomechanical assay for the detection of cancer cells in pre-clinical models. Overall, this research will yield valuable insights to the mechanobiology of invadopodia, and potentially create a new tool for assessing biomechanically the probability that cancer cells will invade.  As part of the research project, the investigators will provide summer research opportunities to undergraduate students recruited through the NSF LSAMP IINSPIRE program which recruits underrepresented undergraduate students to labs for summer research. Also a one-day workshop featuring aspects of the research imaging progress will be created for 60 undergraduates in the PI's university department at Iowa State.

The invadopodium is a protein complex formed in cancer cell membranes which is and involved in matrix degradation and cancer metastasis. Mechano-sensitive protein integrins are expected to transmit force to critically regulate the formation and function of invadopodia. However, such force has not been studied in invadopodia due to previous technical barriers. The goal of this project is to characterize integrin-transmitted molecular tension (integrin tension) and investigate its fundamental role in the formation and function of invadopodia. Using innovative molecular tension tools developed by the PI, the research in this project will first calibrate and image integrin tension in invadopodia with high resolution and sensitivity. Integrin tension and various structural proteins will be co-imaged at 0.3 micron resolution to reveal the force-structure interplay in invadopodia. Next, integrin tension will be globally and quantitatively knocked down to a designed level using a tension modulator, the consequent structural deficiency and function loss of invadopodia in matrix degradation will be examined to determine the role of integrin tension in the activities of invadopodia. At last, high-resolution tension map contributed by integrins in both invadopodia and focal adhesions will be tested as a biomarker for the identification of cancer cells from a large population of regular cells. This unique biomechanical assay has the potential to provide a fast and convenient approach for the detection of circulating tumor cells in patient blood samples.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: IOWA STATE UNIVERSITY OF SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY

por.por_cntn:
This project studied the molecular forces within a distinctive cell membrane structure known as the invadosome. Invadosomes typically form on the cell membranes of cancer cells or white blood cells, presenting as dot-shaped structures with a micrometer-scale diameter. Each cell generates numerous invadosomes, often totaling in the tens. These invadosomes serve dual functions: facilitating cell adhesion to the local tissue structure and enzymatically degrading tissue components. As a result, invadosomes play a role in the migration of cancer cells and the breakdown of local tissue structures, enabling cancer cells to break free from their original tumor sites and promoting the occurrence of cancer metastasis.

On the other hand, the function of invadosomes in macrophages remains less clear. However, they might serve as a potential mechanism for macrophage migration and the degradation of proteins or DNA materials released by pathogens or deceased cells. One particular protein named integrin is a critical component in the structure of invadosomes. Integrin provides the physical linkage between cells and the local tissues. In invadosomes, integrins form a circular ring that surrounds a core structure at the center. Through integrins, invadosomes stay adherent to the tissue structures. Integrins are known to transmit forces, which participate in the activation of the integrin signaling pathway.

Just like other biochemical signals, the forces transmitted by integrins in invadosomes are essential for the function of invadosomes and the subsequent behaviors of cancer cells and immune cells. However, unlike biochemical or structural signals, forces are much more difficult to study, as they are typically invisible and intangible at the cellular or molecular scale.

To study these forces in invadosomes, the Wang lab developed molecular tension sensors that convert force signals into light signals. Under a pulling force, these sensors undergo conformational changes, activating an otherwise quenched fluorophore, and therefore reporting the location and magnitude of the force. With this unique technical advance, the Wang lab characterized the integrin-transmitted forces in invadosomes and investigated the role of these forces in the formation and function of invadosomes. The Wang lab revealed that these molecular forces range from 10 to 100 picoNewtons (1 pN = 10^-12 Newton). Interestingly, these forces were found to be dispensable during the formation of invadosomes.

By visualizing and calibrating the integrin forces in the micron-sized invadosomes, the Wang lab achieved the main research goal of this proposal. Moreover, research sponsored by this project has led to multiple serendipitous discoveries and technique development. As the tension sensor was originally made of DNA, the Wang lab revealed that invadosomes in both cancer cells and white blood cells recruit a substantial amount of DNase, an enzyme that degrades DNA. This is a highly interesting discovery that reveals an unknown interaction between invadosomes and the surrounding materials.

On the other hand, to continue the study of invadosome forces, the Wang lab developed DNase-resistant force sensors that are applicable in DNase-present environments, broadening the application of molecular force sensors. To date, the project has produced seven peer-reviewed publications. The synthesis of the DNase-resistant tension sensors has been made publicly available. Two graduate and three undergraduate students were trained in DNA-based nano-engineering. One graduate student proceeded to work as a postdoctoral researcher at the University of California at Berkeley. One undergraduate student was accepted into the graduate program at Northwestern University.

 


Last Modified: 08/30/2023
Modified by: Xuefeng Wang
